bug.cf_doc_type: If docs needed, set a value

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 1260299 example to reproduce the bug
Description of problem: internal compiler error when "const va_list" is used. The problem seems to be the "const". Without "const" it does compile.
Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable): gcc (GCC) 6.2.1 20160916 (Red Hat 6.2.1-2) Does also occur with newer versions.
How reproducible: example file t.c: ---cut--- #include <stdarg.h>
void foo(const va_list a) { int i = va_arg(a,int); } ---cut---
Steps to Reproduce: 1. compile the example above with "gcc t.c"
Actual results: internal compiler error: in build_va_arg, at c-family/c-common.c:5812
I'll have a look, we shouldn't ICE on non-sensical code, but I just have to say that const va_list when you use va_arg on it doesn't make any sense, va_arg of course has to modify it.
This was fixed in r239829 on the trunk. I can backport the fix to 6 if you want (looks safe).

(In reply to Jakub Jelinek from comment #1) > I'll have a look, we shouldn't ICE on non-sensical code, but I just have to > say that const va_list when you use va_arg on it doesn't make any sense, > va_arg of course has to modify it.
You are right. Older versions of GCC compiled this code without any remark. I just wondered about the internal compiler error I suddenly see on a different computer. Maybe an error message or warning is more appropriate, but I just got the info from Marek Polacek that this issue is already fixed in newer versions of GCC on trunk. Though I think I could live with it by rewrite my code.

(In reply to Marek Polacek from comment #2) > This was fixed in r239829 on the trunk. I can backport the fix to 6 if you > want (looks safe).
Dear Marek, thank for doing the research on this. I did not found the commit which fixed this issue, thus I assumed the bug may not be known.
I think it is not needed to do a backport for 6.2. Thank you for your kind offer. I will modify my code by removing the "const" from the source (which is indeed not useful, even older versions of GCC accepted it).
I think the issue can be closed and kept here for documentation purposes.
